So does that mean that a mal-formed XML document is considered a conflict
with the resource?  Further, if the request was a POST where a successful
response would be the creation of a resource, what would the mal-formed XML
document be conflicting with?  The rules of the resource pointed to by the
POST?

And if 409 is what should be used for the mal-formed XML, what would 403 be
used for?

---
Seairth Jacobs
seairth@...

From: "Berend de Boer" <berend@...>
>
> Seairth Jacobs <seairth@...> writes:
>
>     Seairth> Suppose an application detects a problem with the request
>     Seairth> entity.  Should a 403 (forbidden) or a 409 (conflict) be
>     Seairth> returned?
>
> If *access* to the resource is not forbidden, it's not a 403.
>
> I return a 409 for example when the user submits an invalid query
> (invalid SQL/Xpath/whatever).
